top_comment.author: Tanaka Adrian

comments.text:
+nbk9nkg The amount of ignorance in this post is overwhelming to say the 
least. First of we will start with your last statement, "it's called 
faith"- faith by definition is to believe in something without evidence, 
which is why to understand evolution has nothing to do with faith. 
Secondly, you are aware that the reason its commonly refereed to as a 
"theory" isn't because it isn't fact, its simply a label we put on things 
because we don't completely 100% understand it to its entirety. That's why 
its called the "theory" of gravity, learn scientific terminology please. In 
reality, its actually "Darwin's Law AND Theory of Evolution". Evolution is 
a fact, proved by evidence, you don't get to "choose" to believe in it or 
not believe in it on the basis of whim or culture. Go back to reading your 
little book about some tyrannical sky genie written by a bunch of desert 
dwelling savages over two thousand years ago and leave the real science to 
the educated people of this planet. Evolution has all been but proven, all 
we're doing now is just figuring out the exact little details if it all.
comments.author: ComicNoobler

comments.text:
Yes! finally we have a movie genre dedicated to spreading the dogma about a 
tyrannical sky genie, hurray for ignorance!.
comments.author: ComicNoobler

comments.text:
+John Smith That's not what he's saying. He and even myself included are 
glad that they're making faith based movies. Moving the bottle doesn't make 
him the next Christ. This movie and it's genre are about faith.
comments.author: sharp52092

comments.text:
Just because a boy appears to make a bottle movie as part of a Magician's 
parlor trick does not make him the next Jesus Christ
comments.author: John Smith

top_comment.text:
I don't believe in God, but as far as religious movies go, I like this 
approach more than all the other attempts recently. God's not Dead was just 
completely flawed in its depiction of Atheists and Muslims. While I've 
never seen Heaven is For real, I'm sure it's also flawed in a similar way. 
I liked Noah because it took the story in the bible and treated it like 
mythology like with the Greek Gods and I think helped make it a great 
movie. While I'm not interested in this movie I think religious movies 
should try and take a more subtle approach instead of bashing people over 
the head that God is real. Although this trailer could just be misleading. ﻿
top_comment.author: TheBatmanNerd

comments.text:
+TheBatmanNerd That I have to agree with you on. The movie was meant to be 
told from a very singular perspective. But honestly, that's what it sold 
from the very beginning. Truth be told the concept of trying to prove God's 
existence was never something that any individual could truly do. And 
whether people cared for the argument or not, that's one of the main things 
the boy acknowledged in the very beginning. That he couldn't prove God's 
existence and the other side could not disprove it. So two sides were 
basically arguing over something they were simply unable to be absolute 
about. That to me summed up the entire point of most of the religious 
arguments that happen. That's why most of the time people resort to just 
fighting with each other when they run out of stuff to use. So to me the 
movie wasn't meant to teach us factual debates, but just represent how most 
of these arguments happen on a day to day basis in real life. 

But in regards to the atheist and Muslim depiction that is also something I 
never fully got. This movie does not speak for all Christians and it most 
definitely does not speak for all atheists and Muslims. No one should watch 
and think that just because someone of a specific ethnicity and ideology is 
within it that it speaks for every single person of that field. That's just 
a wrong way to look at anything in general to be honest. This movie was 
showing certain kinds of people. And the same way Christianity can have 
hypocritical Christians there can also be hypocritical atheists. And 
believe it or not people do break way from muslim culture to follow other 
religions and they are persecuted for it. But just because it showed one 
family does not mean it spoke for the entire Muslim culture. 

It's fine if you don't see the movie. I'm not trying to convince anyone to 
go see it. I'm just saying there are other things to take from it. And even 
when somethings happened that I didn't agree with in the movie. There were 
still things I could take from it. For me this movie doesn't really teach 
us something, but address things that I feel we should be more open about. 
It's great you have friends of different ideologies. I have several myself. 
Unfortunately contrary to your relationship with your friends. The people I 
know consistently challenge my religion. Most of them are atheists as well. 
So I can't fully agree with when people say most atheists don't care about 
religion, when the experiences I have them tell a different tale. 

But don't misinterpret this as me accusing you of anything. And I'm not 
saying that atheists are bad and that Christians are good. I'm just 
speaking from my personal experiences. And I'm sure you've seen your fair 
share of it as well. People are fighting with each other and it's not all 
harmless name calling.
comments.author: Hannibal Rasberry

comments.text:
+Hannibal Rasberry I'm basically with John Smith on this one. God's Not 
Dead depicted an atheist who was just mad at God, (so therefore not really 
an atheist), also the arguments for and against God were extremely weak in 
the movie, not to mention it barely gave atheists an opportunity to give 
any logical evidence against God.

I know it's a christian movie, but I thought the whole point of the movie 
was to help Christians who find themselves in similar situations in a 
debate against atheists, if that is so, the movie doesn't really help out 
Christians in any way, it just paints a bad picture of atheists and 
Muslims, (all atheists are just mad at God, and that all Muslims are scary 
and abusive).

Also, no professor would ever ask a student to debate for his religion and 
threaten to fail him, it's just a ridiculous concept. Not all atheists are 
mad at God, in fact no real atheist is mad at God, we don't believe in God. 
Most atheists don't care what people believe in, we just don't like it when 
other peoples religion infringes on our lives. Again, I don't hate God or 
Christianity, (my best friend is devoutly christian) and while I don't plan 
on seeing this movie, I have no problem with it, and actually think this 
movie will be good for the christian community.
comments.author: TheBatmanNerd

comments.text:
+Fletchersaurus I can hear your point. But only agree with it so much I'm 
afraid. People change their ideologies because of their life experiences. 
that just comes with the territory of our life. What you speak of his 
someone who is absolute in their way of thinking. And those simply aren't 
as common as we'd like to believe. Even in the religious society they're 
are people who doubt their choice.
comments.author: Hannibal Rasberry

comments.text:
+Hannibal Rasberry One of the real problems with God's Not Dead is that the 
professor was never an atheist to begin with. The whole point of the film 
was that he hated God because of the events in his personal life and it 
tried to portray all atheists as thinking this way, stereotyping them as 
'the bad guy' who hates what you believe in.

An atheist would not have believed in a God to hate in the first place. And 
further, most atheists believe in freedom of religion - believe what you 
want, so long as it is not the detriment of others.
comments.author: Fletchersaurus

comments.text: +John Smith hm, yes you're right there. that I can not argue.
comments.author: Hannibal Rasberry

comments.text:
+Hannibal Rasberry
The ACLU would have a case against a college professor that does an 
assignment. They have stood on both the sides of conservatives and liberals 
since they are a non-partisan organization.
comments.author: John Smith

comments.text:
+John Smith I can't say for sure. I don't know how all atheist college 
professors think. But the debate itself is a very different matter. because 
then you go into very subjective stuff.
comments.author: Hannibal Rasberry

comments.text:
Most Atheists secular. And no Atheist college professor would ever make an

comments.author: John Smith

comments.text:
+TheBatmanNerd I saw the movie God's not Dead, and I actually didn't mind 
the movie. I know a lot of people didn't like the depiction of Atheists and 
Muslims in the movie. But in regards to Atheists i've met my fair share of 
people who acted exactly like many of those characters did in the movie. 
And that's not to say the people themselves were bad. Cause I also never 
thought they were. They just seemed like everyday people as far as I was 
concerned. At the end of the day they had their reasons for the way they 
lived.

That being said the move definitely had it's faults. But I don't think the 
movie was meant to represent all forms of atheists. I don't think any movie 
can do that. There's just way too many elements to consider so it more or 
less narrowed it down to the type of people who consistently fight with 
Christians on a daily basis. Again it's not meant to represent all of them, 
just who a certain kind. The same with how the Christians were shown. In 
regards to the Muslims, I know there are people in those cultures who 
follow Christianity in secret because they are definitely discriminated 
against for it. And some don't end up in good situations because of it. But 
i'd love to hear your thoughts more on the matter.
comments.author: Hannibal Rasberry

comments.text:

got a mate.

comments.text:
+Adrian Rodriguez I wouldn't have mind the concept of faith in the movie. 
Or religion for that matter. But I honestly was not expecting that mountain 
to move. I thought the theme of the movie, would be to teach us how to 
maintain our faith in such troubling and dark times. And being able to 
accept that God does not answer our prayers exactly the way we want, and 
how to cope with them. I seriously thought that's what this movie was going 
to be about. But then the mountain started moving and then that quickly 
fell apart =/. I really wish they had gone the other route though.

comments.text: Same
comments.author: xXBeastxKusherXx

top_comment.text:
It seems that this entire movie is based on the Bible verse Matthew 17:20, 
which states: "Truly I tell you, if you have faith as small as a mustard 
seed, you can say to this mountain, 'Move from here to there,' and it will 
move. Nothing will be impossible for you." Many Christians will flock to 
see this film because it will edify them, but unfortunately, many of them 
will not ask the very hard questions. Why is it, if their faith is real and 
their God is real, why is that they can't move mountains? Why is it that 
they cannot cure world hunger, vanquish cancer, and subdue armed conflict 
around the world? The answer to these questions is obvious. Either they 
really don't believe what they say they believe, or their God isn't real. ﻿
top_comment.author: Drake Santiago

comments.text:
People do not have to be religious to have faith. Nor a building  with

comments.text:
+Drake Santiago I agree. The divide amongst people on these matters has

comments.author: Hannibal Rasberry

comments.text:
I think you have helped me understand why as a Christian I'm not interested 
in this movie. It seems to teach nothing of value and perhaps is even 
damaging due to it's poor portrayal of faith. In Christianity a person with 
absolute faith would only want what God wants anyways. They give their will 
over to God. Moving a mountain to prove a point is selfish and pointless 
and isn't a proper use of faith. If God wanted a literal mountain moved 
then it would be done and if someone plays a roll in that it would only be 
because there was a specific purpose. Faith doesn't give someone super hero 
powers, rather it means someone has turned their will over to God and is 
most likely manifested in service to others.
comments.author: Acey Infinity

comments.text:
+Hannibal Rasberry Thank you for writing such a well thought out and open 
minded response. I rarely get to see much of that when I address religious 
issues.
comments.author: Drake Santiago

comments.text:
+Drake Santiago You make a good argument. Unfortunately I am not to sure 
myself what to make of that proverb. Or this film for that matter. The cold 
reality is that there are many things that Christians myself included are 
still trying to figure out on a daily basis. And one of the things we keep 
running into is that some things are not as simply stated at they appeared 
in the text. This seems to be another one of those cases. Where we read 
something in the Bible, and have to figure out what exactly was meant by 
it. And if we fully understand what it is asking us for or if what it says 
the outcome will be is clear as well. But the ultimatum you stated does sum 
it up in most of our minds. Either we do not fully believe in the words we 
say or what we follow is wrong. That's often the biggest challenge we face 
with our ideology. And that form of self doubt is not easy to ward off. 
Especially when those who follow our religions have their own view points 
on the matter as well.
comments.author: Hannibal Rasberry

comments.text:
I have a better chance of appealing to a fellow human for mercy or help 
than I do some sky genie. God (and the gods) is a concept created by man to 
help him deal with the unknown in life. If the religious concept of faith 
brings comfort to people that's fine. But i feel we should look to each 
other to solve our problems as opposed to waiting for God to save us. The 
only one who can save us is us.
comments.author: KC Nwaneri

comments.text: +Mami Burger So moving the goalpost?
comments.author: RiotKurhein

comments.text:
Well It isn't my place to judge other people, but I would guess most people 
don't have immense faith. For example, when Jesus says "size of mustard 
seed", it seems very small to us, but Jesus' point is that, humans don't 
even have that much. Imagine if the mustard seeds value was set at 
1,000,000. That is a lot. Jesus, compares 1,000,000 to a mustard seed 
because, the other end of the spectrum is infinity. 1,000,000 is nothing to 
God because of infinity. But to humans 1,000,000 is huge. So again, Jesus' 
point was that we don't even have faith like a mustard seed.
comments.author: Mami Burger

title: Little Boy 2015 Official Trailer + Trailer Review : Beyond The Trailer
